rulesGeneral Rules

1) All sitewide rules apply. Read them here
2) Rainbow is my color. No using it under any circumstances, and no impersonating or pretending to impersonate the mod.
3) Play to your faction's win condition, as long as you do not break any game or site rules in doing so.
4) You may not discuss this game anywhere outside the game thread unless explicitly permitted to do so in your role PM.
5) Directly quoting your role PM, QT or private communications with the mod is strictly forbidden. Loose paraphrasing is permitted.
6) I expect every player to be civil and to treat eachother with respect. Mafia is a heated game, but I'll interfere if anyone resorts to excessive insults, personal attacks, or bullying.
7) No weird forms of encryption. Crumbing is perfectly OK.

Voting/Lynching Mechanics

I) For your vote or unvote to be counted, it must either be in the form of Vote: Aeronaut or VOTE: Aeronaut. Nicknames/abbreviations are fine as long as I know who you're talking about.
II) A lynch will occur when >50% of the votes are cast for the same player. (E.G. if there are 9 people left in-game, 5 votes insures a lynch)
III) You may vote for "no lynch" if you wish. If >50% of the players in the game vote for no-lynch, the game will progress to night without a lynch.
IV) Alternatively, if the lynching deadline passes and a majority of votes for one player is not reached, there will be a "No Lynch", and the game will progress to night without a lynch.
IV) If you are killed, you may make one tasteful "Bah" post, but it must 100% non revealing of any sort of game information, or anything of that sort. It must be a farewell only.
V) Twilight phase talking is allowed.

Activity and Deadlines

I) Each Day phase will last [number of living players + 4] days. For example, if there are 7 players left in the game, you will have 11 days.
II) Deadlines will be extended for replacement situations and exceptional circumstances.
III) Night phases will last for 48 hours.
IV) In order to be accepted, night/day actions must be PMed to the mod. If a player does not select one, he or she will default to "no action."
V) Players will be prodded after forty-eight hours without posting. All prods will be announced in thread.
VI) Players who do not respond to a prod within twenty-four hours or need to be prodded three times in a game phase will be force-replaced.
VII) If you will be unable to post for over forty-eight hours, inform the mod by PM or in the thread of when you'll be V/LA. Assuming the V/LA period is of reasonable length, you will be exempt from prods during that time. All V/LA notifications will be made public by the mod.
VIII)Please keep the game active! If you're in like ten other games and are planning on lurking through this, just replace out.

Other

I) I reserve the right to add, remove, or modify rules at any point of the game if it becomes necessary.
II) Pretending to break the rules is just as bad as breaking them, and will be taken just as seriously.
III) If you feel like I've missed something, or you feel I need to take action about something, please let me know in-thread or by PM.



Sample Townie PMWelcome to Refraction Mafia!

You are a Vanilla Townie. You may vote during the day.

You win when all threats to the Town have been eliminated.

The game thread is here.
Sending out role PMs. Game will start when 11 out of 13 have confirmed!
While you wait:

Day 1 Start!



(expired on 2015-06-28 23:00:32)

You feel your very particles begin to break apart into subatomic fractures... Your very core is ripped from you and you begin to split. Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo and Violet just to name a few, they're all shining from the clear glass prism. A once brilliant white light is now split into different hues and frequency, creating an elegant array of every color known to man.

The only way to regain your former brilliance is to recombine with your fellow colors. However, Beware; There are more colors here than meet the eye. Hold true, shine bright, and you may just lead your team to victory.

Welcome to Refraction Mafia.

Point by point:
1) Yeah, his meta read on you was dumb. Not scummy, just dumb. (Meta is dumb don't use it. It's a siren song that even I fall prey to some times, but it leads me astray so often. It's confirmation bias land) You talked it through, he changed his mind and moved away.
2) I think his post about Texcat was pretty okay. What about it was scummy, in your opinion? I already layed out why I think Plotonius' claim to be able to read you is towny, so it strikes me that someone pushing against that (as Texcat was in this case) is something worth questioning. He votes more freely than you or I do, obviously, but that's a style thing, not an alignment indicator, imo.
3) Slayer's Gambit is dumb. Never do it unless you have a really good way to prove your own towniness, because it tanks your credibility (because you're acting objectively scummy). It's honey-potting, and you need a good way to tell the difference between 'scum lured into your honey pot' and 'town that voted you because you're doing something objectively scummy'. It also turns 'I refuse to participate' into a towny action, which it very much isn't. Once you start assuming that everyone acting purposefully obstinate is town, you get into a degenerate case where scum can just refuse to play, be town read for it, and win by not playing. That's no fun.
4) I agree that his push on you was shitty. Conveniently he changed his mind when faced with updated information. His push on Texcat was pretty okay. Also, hypocrisy is a null tell. Plenty of town are hypocrites, whether they want to admit it or not.
5 & 6) Those are 'Pressure votes'. Basically people are shaking their fists at Lapsa and yelling "You better start playing or we'll kill you!" They're trying to force him to participate. Personally I don't think it's the best way to engage an obstinate player (see: My questions / talk with Lapsa. I find curated engagement works better) but it's the far more common way to handle the situation. If someone refuses to play, that is anti-town. It's pretty much the definition of a policy lynch. You do it because you're trying to create a 'policy' where people must participate and refusing to do so is unacceptable.
Making it clear that his actual scum read is on Abuse is towny, because if Abuse gets lynched while MathDino is camping on a Lapsa vote, we can hold MathDino responsible for that read. If push comes to shove and MathDino refuses to vote that read, we can hold him responsible for that too.

7) Policy lynches are a really controversial subject. Some people really love them, some people (like me, and obviously you), don't. But that's not usually alignment indicating. Things like refusing to participate just suck to deal with. Making it not-okay to do that is a pro-fun maneuver, if not always pro-town.
Lapsa is acting anti-town. Full stop. He's not helping us find the scum, and he's not helping us get a read on him. Other than metaing "Oh, he must be doing X gambit" we have no real way to determine his alignment. If you didn't know he was gambiting, what would your read on him be?
My method to get a read on him is to coax him into participating. MadDino's (and others, and it's the more conventional way to handle it) is to threaten him into participating. Pressure voting here is actually a pro-town action, as much as that sounds backwards, because it puts Lapsa into a position where he has to produce some content to help us get a read on him.

Intent is to see the entire game as a big picture, and as such I take a few moments every now and then to reevaluate the entire game to make SURE I'm not tunneling. And as time goes on in D1 I'm more likely to be right.

This means I drop cases instantly when I see obvious townposting.

This means I drop cases instantly when the reason I'm voting someone is nullified by them.

And in my opinion for how I think, that's the optimal playstyle I have. Because I'm not going to be right from the beginning, I'm going to delude myself into a few bullshit pushes just to get my bearings. And then the ball gets rolling and I change my mind. Right now I really like a texcat push because this Plotinus wagon? It's certainly bullshit. And I'm surprised barely anyone's even commented on the texcat thing in the past, what, 8 pages? So I need to reread. Reevaluate.

tl;dr: Fuck everyone who thinks I should be lynched for being bad at scumhunting off the bat.

And hell, Thor, from my standpoint 100% of your votes are dumb or not scumhunting. Zor (prior to this clusterfuck of a last 8 pages) is my top townread, and BBT is correct that you're focusing on literally no one else. I said I have no interest in lynching you because I think you're a good player and I want to work with you, but so far in my eyes you're doing NOTHING helpful to find scum. And on the flip side I haven't seen you reevaluate once. This isn't me trying to be all "oh ho ho, maybe everyone voting me is scum" and cast suspicion wildly. This is me speaking to you as a player, do you actually have no other reads that I can work with? And if so please link me to them because I may just have read right over them.

Addendum: Not sure if this helps or not but I haven't mentioned this because I thought it'd be weird/awkward. First thing I did before I posted was look at Thor's wiki. And the only thing I remember from it was to ALWAYS be using your vote for something. And that's been in the back of my mind this game and has influenced specifically my playstyle this game, and that's why I was talking about voting Lapsa because that's where I felt my vote was best served. So first thing I'm probably gonna do in post-game is ask everyone who's played more than I have, "WTF did I do wrong this time?" Unless you're scum, in which case, you know, respect for casing me and all that shit.

Whatever. Insight into my mind. Continuing to read, will post catchup or reads list at some point.

OK so my case on Frogger is essentially that he appears to be trying to appease people in an effort to avoid being scumread while pushing wagons on town. The reason I think this is because of his vote-sheeping and changing his votes after criticism.

Sheeping

Here I use the term "sheeping" to mean "borrowing reasoning from other players as justification for a vote." The scum explanation is that Frogger is trying to appease the players he's sheeping by using their logic, having trouble coming up with reasoning of his own or is otherwise trying to shield himself from criticism because he knows at least one other person agrees with his reasoning.

-Frogger voted Lapsa in #94 re-using the argument that he was fluffposting and therefore not contributing to town.
-Jumps off the Lapsa wagon in #140 re-using the argument that Lapsa wouldn't continue to act the same way if he was scum.
-Votes Plotinus in #280 using at least some of CB's reasoning.
-Votes me in #338 using texcat's reasoning (admits it explicitly).
-Votes Thor in #565, not necessarily using others' logic but definitely taking advantage of momentum. Which is similar because it allows him to shield himself behind other players.

Changing votes after criticism

The scum explanation for changing his votes after criticism is that he's hoping to avoid being scumread, or possibly that he's trying to follow the cues of partners.

-Frog's switch from plot to me in #338 was precipitated by Thor's criticism of Frog's plot case in #314.
-Frog's unvoting of plot in #515 was precipitated by criticism from abuse, and I feel like there were others too.
-Frog's unvoting of Lapsa in #134 uses logic others have given criticizing the Lapsa wagon.

A couple other things

-Frog's reasoning for unvoting Lapsa was that he couldn't see Lapsa acting so scummy if he were actually scum (in so many words). Which goes against his reasoning for voting Lapsa in the first place: that Lapsa's fluffposting was scummy. Which is fine, you know, people change their minds. Except that in #140, not long after Frog hopped off the Lapsa wagon, he criticized Math for using pretty much the exact same reasoning.
-Frog tried to adopt reasoning behind his RVS vote on Lapsa (that Lapsa was the last to confirm). Which, why do RVS votes need reasoning in the first place? And beyond that, how does that resemble solid reasoning for why a player is scum? Then Frogger actually follows up on it and goes to investigate when Lapsa's last posting was, using that as justification for unvoting Lapsa later. It just looks like him playing very cautiously and trying to justify things that don't need justifying because he's afraid of the way he'll look if he doesn't back up his moves.

I'm off work in about an hour, so expect my connection to be spotty until then.

A note for reading this: I'm using my memory of the overall argument, verified and supported by individual posts I have found via the ISO function, to construct this post. Thor, Math and Zor have rehashed these arguments multiple times. I've done my best to find single posts that clearly illustrate what has happened.

If I missed something in here that makes any of these points moot or contradicts them because I focused on those individual posts and not others, please let me know.

Spoiler: What I think of Thor's case on Zor
-Thor says Zor is defending Math based on something Math has refuted: Specifically, Thor charges Zor with insisting that Math admitted his meta on Frogger was wrong, while Math later said that he didn't say this. The place this breaks down is Thor's argument that Math refuted Zor's claim that Math admitted to the meta being bad. The post I believe Thor is referring to is #158. The trouble is, Math is not refuting that claim from Zor. Math is refuting the claim that Math unvoted Frog because of people's disagreement with Math's case on Frog, not because Zor was wrong about Math admitting that the meta was bad. Now onto the point of whether Math actually admitted the meta was bad. Zor gives #57 as evidence...I see no evidence to back up Zor's claim. Does that make Zor scum? Let's talk about that in this next point.
-Thor says Zor is not reading the game because he's said something about Math that Math has refuted: I don't think you can call someone scummy for not reading the game. Town do this...all the time. Tex has openly admitted to doing the same and Thor has openly admitted to not having any thoughts on Tex, so.
-Thor says Zor is too confident for townreading Math: Does Zor's confidence in Math based on the assertion that Math admitted to being wrong fall for lack of evidence? Yes. Does Zor give other, less fallible evidence for townreading Math? Yes (see: #144). Do I agree with this evidence? No. Does that make Zor look scummy? Meh.
-Thor says Zor tries to move on from the debate by dismissing it as "different interpretations": After a certain point, it was different interpretations. Like, you continued to push Zor saying that Math admitted to being wrong, and Zor said "OK, but regardless of whether Math said that I think he looks town for agreeing that Frog looked towny and moving on." This could be scum trying to escape pressure, sure, but I see no reason to think that over town trying to defend themselves against a mislynch/moving on from a protracted argument about the same ol' shit.


Spoiler: What I think of Zor based on the back and forth
-Zor's interaction with Thor based on this whole thing does not lead me to believe he's scum. It's not a reason to townread him, either. Unfortunately I've had to consider his actions in the context of this back and forth before considering his ISO as a whole. That much, I believe, will give me a better indication on Zor.
-Basically what Zor is saying throughout this is "I see no reason to think Math is scum." Which is fine. His rebuttals to Thor's case don't strike me as being weird. Does he possibly misinterpret some shit? Yeah. Does he forget stuff and openly admit to skimming certain things? Yep. Does that make him scummy? Maybe if that supported some larger scummy thing he's doing I guess....I don't really see it...
-Zor's reasoning for thinking Math is town is a little thin, yes. He says he thinks Math is town for agreeing that Frog was scum and for then moving on. Which gives more deference, too easily I think, to the town explanation over the scum explanation (the scum explanation being that Math got uncomfortable with the pressure based on Frog's vote and therefore switched away to dial down the pressure). He also doesn't seem to see what's wrong with Math's vote on texcat, which I thought was weird too. Now the question is, why does Zor not see these things? Is it because he's scum who either doesn't want to (because Math is a partner, perhaps) or because he has no genuine reason to be more paranoid about Math? Maybe. Or maybe, like most people in this fast-paced game, he's handling the volume of activity by dialing down his efforts on some players and ramping it up on others. Or maybe he just sees the game differently.


Spoiler: What I think of Thor based on the back and forth
-The building up of this feels natural just based on the progression (Thor pushes math -> Zor defends Math -> Thor argues with Zor -> Thor votes Zor). But I also think that that is well within the bounds of how Thor would develop fake reads as scum.
-What I do think is significant is sentences like the one at the end of #208. He calls out Zor for his thought that Math doesn't look scummy now that he's dropped scummy reasoning. Which makes sense, logically to me. Like, person was scummy -> person stopped being scummy -> person is no longer scummy. But Thor acts like it's super weird and calls it unnatural. And this is something Thor has essentially pushed Zoronos into saying through questioning. Either scumThor pushed Zoronos until he said something he thought he could capitalize on, then used it to start building a case against Zor, or townThor was pushing for a Math lynch and through his pushing found somebody he thought looked worse. The reasoning for calling Zor's defense "unnatural" in this post is what tips the scale toward the scum explanation for me.
-#533 is, I think, the point that makes the foundation of Thor's case: that Zor is defending Math based on something that Thor says is not true, and that Thor says Math has pointed out as not being true. Which is, like...a misunderstanding, IMO. It just feels like thin reasoning and I don't understand why it's enough for Thor to change his vote, especially when he's still scumreading Math.

-I suppose where that leaves me is that it does not do much to sway my earlier read on him.

Plot:

-Has me as maybe-town in #439.
-Continues to townread me, often for following a similar thought pattern as him, throughout his ISO.
-As far as I can tell, Plot never actually addresses the flashwagon on me. Which is, by itself suspicious...except that I townread plot for unrelated reasons.

BBT:

-Unfortunately the short version of my username (which is the most common way people refer to me) is also a word in BBT's signature, which makes it very hard for me to find myself in his ISO. Old-fashioned way it is!
-BBT is suspicious of me to start off with, pretty much for the same early-game reasons everyone else who's suspicious of me has used. #442 is a nice summary.
-Begins to ask me questions about my case, and basically realizes that I'm town when I show that I have a legitimate thought process behind it, even if he doesn't agree. I try to look at interactions with my own slot objectively, and this is a somewhat town maneuver. It certainly wouldn't have been controversial to push me at the time, and BBT already had stated suspicion of me.
-The predominant feature of BBT's interaction with my flashwagon is annoyance that it's distracting from the Thor wagon. By the time the flashwagon had begun, BBT had pretty much decided that I look town and was putting all his efforts into building the Thor wagon. Which is dead-on exactly the way he played the last time we were in a game together, when we were both town. Besides, I don't see a way to argue that that arc is improbable for town. So.

Lapsa:

-Hard to say. In #828 I think he's townreading me, for an early-game post I made.
-Then in #837 he says he'll scumread me if I vote Thor.
-Then I vote Thor, and in #1041 it seems like he's scumreading me?
-Has not voted me, however, and does not appear to have commented on the flashwagon on me. Then again, how often does Lapsa comment on any specific thing going on in the game? I feel like it's kind of a crapshoot. So I don't see any alignment-indicative stuff either way.

Zor:

-The vast majority of Zor's mentions of me are basically in the same place BBT ended up on me: He leans town on me for my posting, but doesn't agree with my case. He questions texcat a little for her read on me, but that looks more like trying to develop a read on texcat than it does defending me. In #858 Zor says he's leaning town on me.
-The only thing that kind of looks like an interaction with my flashwagon from Zor is #1120, and it's only kind of an interaction with my flashwagon because it's addressed to Shin. Other than that his thoughts on my wagon are conspicuously absent.
-Which is suspicious.

Overall: It would make sense to me for there to be two scum off the wagon and one on, especially given that there are more than two players not on the wagon who didn't have much to say about my flashwagon. I believe a couple of them were also in catch-up mode or not really around at the time of this. For instance, if abuse is scum then that would help explain why the wagon never got past L-2. The one-on, two-off theory fits in pretty well with the wagon building up to L-2 but never getting past that -- scum at that point would likely be worried about looking opportunistic for hopping on.

Which is just awesome because I feel like most people are townreading Shinobi too. Hey, maybe people will take this analysis seriously once I flip town. I still pretty much expect to be lynched today.

key:
+ positive interactions (buddying, agreeing with, sheeping, defending, supporting, working together with)
- negative interactions (attacking, pushing, making cases, bussing)
= neutral interactions
v voting
u unvoting
+? unsure if positive interaction
-? unsure if negative interaction

key parts are where a read changes from + to - or visa versa. it is worrying it the reads don’t change at all or if the reasons for the changes aren’t good. it is better later when you can colour it in according to flips.

OK well here's what I had typed up. I'm going to spoiler it since it seems like people weren't really considering lynching between investigative claims today anyway.

Spoiler: Thoughts
So I kind of feel like scum would go after the masons first? Especially since there's still some doubt floating around about the two investigative claims. So it's possible two scum factions go after the same target, and that would be nice for us because that's one less town killed at night, one more conftown the next day and (probably) two more investigation results -- though we would still have to sort out whether we trust them. If we mislynch today, assuming multiball, this scenario would leave us at 8:2:1. That means that if we mislynch the next day and scum get off two kills, we would be at 5:2:1 (however at this point we could have more investigation results, making the game much easier to win -- also, scum could kill scum again and that would be p cool). If we lynch correctly, we are either at 8:2 or 8:1:1. If it's 8:2, then we've eliminated the double kill each night, so a mislynch would bring town to 6:2, then another would bring town to 4:2 and that would be MyLo (and again, we'd hopefully be looking at some investigative results). If it's 8:1:1 and scum don't kill each other, a mislynch would bring town to 5:1:1, and another would bring town to 2:1:1 and then the remaining town would just be deciding which scum faction they want to win.

Then there's the scenario where both scum factions hit town tonight (this is obviously assuming we don't eliminate one mafia faction today via lynch). If we've mislynched, that puts town at 7:2:1, and another mislynch/double NK would put us at 4:2:1. If we've lynched correctly and hit the smaller mafia faction, we're at 7:1:1, and another mislynch/double NK leaves us at 4:1:1.

So all of this is basically to add some background before trying to answer the question of "should we consider lynching between investigative role claims today (Thor and Pers)?" You'll notice that all of the above scenarios look a lot better for town -- even the scenarios where we mislynch -- if we have investigative results coming in. For instance, let's consider the absolute worst case scenario, where we lynch (non-investigative claim) town today and scum eliminate two town tonight (let's say the masons). We're at 7:2:1, but at that point the cops could have cut the list of possible scum down to three...of which three would have to be scum.

This is assuming both investigative role claims are town. So I guess what I'm saying is, if we were to lynch among investigative role claims, we could be preventing ourselves from solving the game pretty quickly.

Whereas if one of them is scum and we leave them out of the lynch pool today, it lowers our chances of hitting scum among the remaining (non-investigative, non-mason claim) possibilities. But even in that case, we've still eliminated a possibility among that pool of question marks and we should have a chance to sort out the cop claims later.

There's also the added benefit that if one of the cop claims is really scum, the other scum faction will be trying to eliminate them. So that's cool.

To add to Pers's assertion that scum would kill investigative claims first, that's even better reason not to lynch between Thor and Pers today.


tl;dr -- it makes sense to me that we exclude Thor and Pers from the lynch list today.

So, next I will be going through the ISOs of the remaining lynch options for today: Shin, RC, Bella and Zor.

[quote="In post 2593, toolenduso”]
And I like Plot's technique for associatives. Makes things easier to wrap your brain around.[/quote]

I used it better in We Didn’t Playtest This. It’s more of a late game technique; on day 1 it’s only good for “are this person’s reads progressing at all or not”, but it’s pretty overpowered later on.

Watching people try to interpret the numbers from the dead thread was pretty interesting, Lapsa was right when he complained about it: if you haven’t just been through a person’s ISO with a fine toothed comb examining every single sentence on the level of “what is this person saying about this other person and what effect is this having on the game state, when they agree with this person who is being attacked, when they push someone who is being defended”, then you don’t know what the + or - sign means; it could be as innocuous as a townie townreading someone else correctly, it could be scum buddying or whiteknighting somebody, it could be a townie being wrong about their reads, or of course it could be scum being reluctant to bus their buddy or subtlely coaching their buddy or trying to tie their buddy in particular to a bunch of other people. You have to have it all fresh in your mind to be able to say what the pattern means; but it’s pretty powerful if you do it right. It’s also good for seeing whether someone’s stances match their voting patterns well or not.

It also helps me by slowing my reading of an ISO down to this glacial pace where I’m seeing all the fine details and it’s almost like i’m looking at the game state from their eyes and I can start to see their mindset and how they’re trying to effect the game state, what they’re trying to accomplish and from there it’s easier for me to see what their motivations are and which wincon they’re furthering.

A lot of people can get reads in a less time consuming fashion but I’m more of a late game player and the numbers thing helps me to see a bunch of subtle stuff that I’d totally miss otherwise and additionally the stuff I tend to complain about is stuff that’s harder to fake as scum.

my supertheory about autism and curing it more or less is that it has a lot to do with perception of time

learning to consciously let oneself to miss things and trying to perceive larger intervals of time helps

but then again - quite likely that's just my ignorance. and I'm not even sure that autism can be called as disease - mind adaptation to crazy times we are living in
